pageProps.body:
Permutations and Cycles

What happens when a mathematician tries to comb their perm? Nothing good; everything goes out of order.

Permutations

A permutation is a way to arrange things in a line in order: students in a lunch line, pens in a pencilcase, people in your group of friends - no, wait, it turns out there's only one permutation for that, I'm sorry to say. Sometimes there are very few ways to do so; sometimes there are a lot, like there being more ways to organize my Magic: The Gathering collection then there are atoms in the universe. If lining things up and ordering them really is a sign of autism, then mathematicians truly embody the phrase, "I don't struggle with autism - I'm actually very good at it."

Permutations are very natural candidates for becoming group members because they swap things around but don't actually change anything substantial, they can and will backtrack on everything they do, and they can do ten different steps before realizing they could've done it in one step and saved all the effort. Groups involving permutations have a very simple definition:

Definition. Define a permutation of a set X={x1,x2,...,xn}X = \{x_1, x_2, ..., x_n\}X={x1​,x2​,...,xn​} as a function f(x)f(x)f(x) which re-orders XXX: for i=1,2,...,ni = 1, 2, ..., ni=1,2,...,n, fff maps xix_ixi​ to another element in the list xjx_jxj​, with the condition that the set {f(x1),f(x2),...,f(xn)}\{f(x_1), f(x_2), ..., f(x_n)\}{f(x1​),f(x2​),...,f(xn​)} is identical to XXX - i.e. fff changes the order of XXX but does not change the elements themselves. We stipulate that fff is invertible; its inverse ggg reverses the permutation, such that (f∘g)=(g∘f)=Id(f\circ g) = (g \circ f) = Id(f∘g)=(g∘f)=Id, the identity function that maps every element of the set to itself.

Call the list of all permutations of the set X={1,2,...,n}X = \{1,2,...,n\}X={1,2,...,n} the nnnth permutation group, denoted SnS_nSn​; for a general set XXX, instead denote this group by Sym(X)\text{Sym}(X)Sym(X), called the symmetric group of XXX.

Theorem. For any set XXX, the triple (Sym(X),∘,Id)(\text{Sym}(X), \circ, Id)(Sym(X),∘,Id) indeed forms a group; if all the elements of XXX are distinct, this group will have order n!n!n! This arises directly from the definition of a permutation: a combination of two permutations is still a permutation, as is the inverse a permutation.

(If at any time there is ambiguity between me being excited about something and me writing a factorial, it's always a factorial.)

Cycles

A very specific type of permutation is

Definition. The kkk-cycle. Let {a1,a2,...,ak}\{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\}{a1​,a2​,...,ak​} be a subset of {1,2,...,n}\{1, 2, ..., n\}{1,2,...,n}, all unique and in any order. The kkk-cycle of these elements, denoted (a1a2...ak)(a_1a_2...a_k)(a1​a2​...ak​), is a permutation that changes the order of these elements in the following ways:

  1. Initially, the element at position iii in the set is aia_iai​. (Assumed with loss of generality; we simply label the element in the iiith position aia_iai​, not caring about sorting them in ascending order.) (I had to physically restrain myself from typing position i−1i-1i−1 instead of position iii. Words cannot describe how much I loathe Python for this.)
  2. If iii is not the final position kkk, the element that will occupy position iii is the next element ai+1a_{i+1}ai+1​ instead: (a1a2...ak)(i)=ai+1(a_1a_2...a_k)(i) = a_{i+1}(a1​a2​...ak​)(i)=ai+1​. In essence, every element is shifted leftward by one position: ai+1a_{i+1}ai+1​ is shifted to position iii.
  3. If iii is the final position kkk, the element that will occupy it under the kkk-cycle is a1a_1a1​, the first element; it's gone so far left it has nowhere else to go and finds itself on the extreme right instead, which is a sentence usually reserved for describing the lifecycles of most political Reddit forums.
  4. The kkk-cycle does not change the positions of any elements outside of {a1,a2,...,ak}\{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\}{a1​,a2​,...,ak​}; if m=1,2,...,nm=1, 2, ..., nm=1,2,...,n is not part of this aforementioned set, (a1a2...ak)(m)=m(a_1a_2...a_k)(m) = m(a1​a2​...ak​)(m)=m.

More formally, we write

(a1a2...ak)(i)={ai+1, i≠k, i∈{a1,a2,...,ak}a1,i=k, i∈{a1,a2,...,ak}i,i∉{a1,a2,...,ak}(a_1a_2 ... a_k)(i) = \begin{cases} a_{i+1},\ i \neq k,\ i \in \{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\} \\ a_1, i = k,\ i \in \{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\} \\ i, i \notin \{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\} \end{cases}(a1​a2​...ak​)(i)=⎩⎨⎧​ai+1​, i=k, i∈{a1​,a2​,...,ak​}a1​,i=k, i∈{a1​,a2​,...,ak​}i,i∈/{a1​,a2​,...,ak​}​

treating the kkk-cycle as a function of position iii (which it certainly is).

What a revolution does to the entrenched social hierarchies of a thousand-year monarchy, a kkk-cycle does to {a1,a2,...,ak}\{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\}{a1​,a2​,...,ak​}. Every layer of the social stratosphere, from the lowly servant aka_kak​ to the well-born a3a_3a3​, join forces to topple the vile despot a1a_1a1​ into poverty and obscurity; freedom and democratic governance are promised until the scheming a2a_2a2​ snabs the crown.

Note that a kkk-cycle repeated kkk times returns the list to its original order!

Definition. Call a 222-cycle (a1a2)(a_1 a_2)(a1​a2​), whose only purpose is to swap the two elements back and forth, a transposition. (My professor tells me I'm not allowed to call them bicycles anymore.)

Definition. Let (a1a2...ak)(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)(a1​a2​...ak​) and (b1b2...bl)(b_1 b_2 ... b_l)(b1​b2​...bl​) be two cycles (of possibly different lengths). If {a1,a2,...,ak}\{a_1, a_2, ..., a_k\}{a1​,a2​,...,ak​} and {b1,b2,...,bl}\{b_1, b_2, ..., b_l\}{b1​,b2​,...,bl​} do not share any common elements - i.e. their intersection is the null set - call the two cycles disjoint: they act on entirely different elements, and thus do not interfere with one another.

Compositions of cycles

Definition. Composition of cycles. Cycles are functions; as such, if σ\sigmaσ and τ\tauτ denote two cycles, the notation στ(i)\sigma \tau(i)στ(i) is understood to be σ(τ(i))\sigma(\tau(i))σ(τ(i)) - first the cycle τ\tauτ applied to iii, then σ\sigmaσ.

Lemma. Disjoint cycles are commutative.

Proof.

Let σ=(a1a2...ak)\sigma = (a_1 a_2 ... a_k)σ=(a1​a2​...ak​) and τ=(b1b2...bl)\tau = (b_1 b_2 ... b_l)τ=(b1​b2​...bl​) be two disjoint cycles, with none of the aia_iai​s and bjb_jbj​s equalling one another (by definition of disjoint cycles). By the definition of a cycle given above, we have σ(i)\sigma(i)σ(i) if i≠a1,...,aki \neq a_1, ..., a_ki=a1​,...,ak​ and τ(i)\tau(i)τ(i) if i≠b1,..,bli \neq b_1, .., b_li=b1​,..,bl​; any iii cannot be part of both {a1,...,ak}\{a_1, ..., a_k\}{a1​,...,ak​} and {b1,b2,...,bl}\{b_1, b_2, ..., b_l\}{b1​,b2​,...,bl​} at once as they have intersection ∅\emptyset∅. Thus, either σ(i)=i\sigma(i) = iσ(i)=i or τ(i)=i\tau(i) = iτ(i)=i; in addition, if iii is not in {a1,...,ak}\{a_1, ..., a_k\}{a1​,...,ak​}, then neither is τ(i)\tau(i)τ(i) (as τ\tauτ maps from bib_ibi​ to bib_ibi​, none of which are in {a1,...,ak}\{a_1, ..., a_k\}{a1​,...,ak​}.)

In the first case where σ(i)=i\sigma(i) = iσ(i)=i, we have

σ(τ(i))=τ(i) as τ(i)∉ai=τ(σ(i)) as σ(i)=i.\begin{aligned} \sigma(\tau(i)) &= \tau(i)\text{ as $\tau(i) \notin a_i$} \\ &= \tau(\sigma(i)) \text{ as $\sigma(i) =i$}. \end{aligned}σ(τ(i))​=τ(i) as τ(i)∈/ai​=τ(σ(i)) as σ(i)=i.​

Similarly, for τ(i)=i\tau(i) = iτ(i)=i we have

τ(σ(i))=σ(i) as σ(i)∉bi=σ(τ(i)) as τ(i)=i.\begin{aligned} \tau(\sigma(i)) &= \sigma(i)\text{ as $\sigma(i) \notin b_i$} \\ &= \sigma(\tau(i)) \text{ as $\tau(i) =i$}. \end{aligned}τ(σ(i))​=σ(i) as σ(i)∈/bi​=σ(τ(i)) as τ(i)=i.​

This completes the proof; the statement can be intuitively understood as saying that if two actions act on different parts of something, then the order in which they are performed does not affect the outcome. This is true for groups and less true for open-heart surgery.

Lemma. Cycles can be cycled: (a1a2a3...ak)(i)=(a2a3...aka1)(i)(a_1a_2a_3...a_k)(i) = (a_2a_3 ... a_k a_1)(i)(a1​a2​a3​...ak​)(i)=(a2​a3​...ak​a1​)(i), and so on.

Proof.

This follows directly from the definition of a cycle:

(a2a3...aka1)(i)={ai+1, i≠1,ka2,i=1a1,i=ki, i≠ai(a_2 a_3 ... a_k a_1)(i) = \begin{cases} a_{i+1},\ i \neq 1, k \\ a_2, i = 1 \\ a_1, i =k \\ i,\ i \neq a_i \end{cases}(a2​a3​...ak​a1​)(i)=⎩⎨⎧​ai+1​, i=1,ka2​,i=1a1​,i=ki, i=ai​​

which corresponds exactly with the original definition of (a1a2...ak)(a_1 a_2 ... a_k)(a1​a2​...ak​).

All of the above leads to the following result:

Theorem. Disjoint cycle decomposition. Every permutation σ\sigmaσ in SnS_nSn​ can be written as a composition of disjoint cycles in which 1,...,n1, ..., n1,...,n all appear, including 111-cycles (ai)(i)(a_i)(i)(ai​)(i) which do not modify the position of any element. The expression

σ=(a11a21...ak11)(a12a22...ak22)...(a1ra2r...akrr)\sigma = (a^1_1 a^1_2 ... a_{k_1}^1) (a^2_1 a^2_2 ... a^2_{k_2}) ... (a^r_1 a^r_2 ... a^r_{k_r})σ=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)(a12​a22​...ak2​2​)...(a1r​a2r​...akr​r​)

is unique barring a reordering of the elements within a cycle, or a reordering of the cycles themselves.

Proof.

Proceed by induction on SnS_nSn​.

The base case, S1S_1S1​, consists of permutations on a set with a single element - this is already a 111-cycle.

Assume that all permutations in SkS_{k}Sk​, k∈Z+k \in \mathbb{Z^+}k∈Z+ and k<nk < nk<n, can be written as a composition of disjoint cycles. In order to prove that all permutations σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​ can be thus decomposed, our goal is to write

σ=τ∘ρ\sigma = \tau \circ \rhoσ=τ∘ρ

where τ\tauτ is a disjoint cycle and ρ\rhoρ is a permutation on Sn−1S_{n-1}Sn−1​ (or fewer elements), which by our strong induction assumption can be decomposed.

To proceed, write τ=σ∘ρ−1\tau = \sigma \circ \rho^{-1}τ=σ∘ρ−1. Consider the sequence 1,σ(1),σ(σ(1))=σ2(1),σ3(1),...,σn(1)1, \sigma(1), \sigma(\sigma(1)) = \sigma^2(1), \sigma^3(1), ..., \sigma^n(1)1,σ(1),σ(σ(1))=σ2(1),σ3(1),...,σn(1); what is the minimum value of kkk such that σk(1)=1\sigma^k(1) = 1σk(1)=1, and the sequence repeats?

As 1,2,...,n1, 2, ..., n1,2,...,n is a finite sequence of numbers, it is impossible that σ(1),...,σk(1),...\sigma(1), ..., \sigma^k(1), ...σ(1),...,σk(1),... are distinct for all kkk; the sequence must repeat at some point. Suppose that σa(1)=σb(1)\sigma^a(1) = \sigma^b(1)σa(1)=σb(1) for some a,ba,ba,b, assuming without loss of generality that a>ba > ba>b; then σa(1)=σa−bσb(1)=σa−bσa(1)=σaσa−b(1)\sigma^a(1) = \sigma^{a-b}\sigma^b(1) = \sigma^{a-b}\sigma^a(1) = \sigma^{a} \sigma^{a-b}(1)σa(1)=σa−bσb(1)=σa−bσa(1)=σaσa−b(1), yielding σa−b(1)=1\sigma^{a-b}(1) = 1σa−b(1)=1 (as a permutation σ\sigmaσ is one-to-one, and σ(a)=σ(b)\sigma(a) = \sigma(b)σ(a)=σ(b) implies a=ba = ba=b.)

In addition to this sequence being finite, by the Pigeonhole Principle there are nnn numbers from 111 to nnn and kkk members of the sequence σ(1),...,σk(1)\sigma(1), ..., \sigma^k(1)σ(1),...,σk(1); if k>nk > nk>n there are n+1n+1n+1 numbers to fit into nnn holes, and at least one value must be repeated. Thus a,b<n+1a, b < n+1a,b<n+1, and a−b≤na - b \leq na−b≤n. a−ba-ba−b is the first positive number satisfying σa−b(1)=1\sigma^{a-b}(1) = 1σa−b(1)=1; call this number kkk, with σk(1)=1\sigma^k(1) = 1σk(1)=1.

The sequence obtained from the above - 1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)1, \sigma(1), ..., \sigma^{k-1}(1)1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1) - is a distinct sequence of numbers, of maximum length nnn (as above): if we had σa(1)=σb(1)\sigma^a(1) = \sigma^b(1)σa(1)=σb(1) with k>a>bk > a > bk>a>b, then as before σa−b(1)=1\sigma^{a-b}(1) = 1σa−b(1)=1 with a−b<ka-b<ka−b<k, violating the assumption that kkk is minimal.

Returning to τ=σ∘ρ−1\tau = \sigma \circ \rho^{-1}τ=σ∘ρ−1, let ρ\rhoρ be the kkk-cycle given by the sequence

ρ=(1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)).\rho = (1, \sigma(1), ..., \sigma^{k-1}(1)).ρ=(1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)).

As all permutations have an inverse, τ\tauτ is well-defined for all σ\sigmaσ. In addition, for m=0,1,...,k−1m = 0, 1, ..., k-1m=0,1,...,k−1 we have

τ(σm(1))=σ(ρ−1(σm(1)))=σ(σm−1(1))=σm(1)\tau(\sigma^m(1)) = \sigma(\rho^{-1}(\sigma^m(1))) = \sigma(\sigma^{m-1}(1)) = \sigma^m(1)τ(σm(1))=σ(ρ−1(σm(1)))=σ(σm−1(1))=σm(1)

Meaning that τ\tauτ is a permutation upon the subset of {1,...,n}\{1, ..., n\}{1,...,n} that excludes {1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)}\{1, \sigma(1), ..., \sigma^{k-1}(1)\}{1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)} - a subset of size strictly less than nnn. By our strong induction assumption, τ\tauτ is thus a composition of disjoint cycles whose expression contains all of {1,...,n}\{1, ..., n\}{1,...,n} barring {1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)}\{1, \sigma(1), ..., \sigma^{k-1}(1)\}{1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)} - and so is σ=τ∘ρ\sigma = \tau \circ \rhoσ=τ∘ρ, ρ\rhoρ itself being a cycle whose expression contains all of {1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)}\{1, \sigma(1), ..., \sigma^{k-1}(1)\}{1,σ(1),...,σk−1(1)}. The two combined give a composition of disjoint cycles where {1,...,n}\{1, ..., n\}{1,...,n} appears in its entirety.

To demonstrate that this decomposition is indeed unique, consider the following equality:

(a11a21...ak11)...(a1ra2r...akrr)=(b11b21...bl11)...(b1sb2s...blss)(a^1_1 a^1_2 ... a^1_{k_1})...(a^r_1 a^r_2 ... a^r_{k_r}) = (b^1_1 b^1_2 ... b^1_{l_1}) ... (b^s_1 b^s_2 ... b^s_{l_s})(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1r​a2r​...akr​r​)=(b11​b21​...bl1​1​)...(b1s​b2s​...bls​s​)

where the two sides are each a decomposition of the permutation σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​. By the above, such a decomposition must contain all of 1,...,n1, ..., n1,...,n; as such, a11=bj1i1a^1_1 = b^{i_1}_{j_1}a11​=bj1​i1​​ for some i1i_1i1​, j1j_1j1​. As permutations can be cycled, we have

a21=bj1+1i1a31=bj1+2i1⋮ak11=bj1+k1−1i1ak1+11=a11=bj1+k1i1\begin{aligned} a^1_2 &= b^{i_1}_{j_1 + 1} \\ a^1_3 &= b^{i_1}_{j_1 + 2} \\ \vdots \\ a^1_{k_1} &= b^{i_1}_{j_1 + k_1 - 1} \\ a^1_{k_1 + 1} = a^1_1 &= b^{i_1}_{j_1 + k_1} \end{aligned}a21​a31​⋮ak1​1​ak1​+11​=a11​​=bj1​+1i1​​=bj1​+2i1​​=bj1​+k1​−1i1​​=bj1​+k1​i1​​​

cycling the indices if necessary; as such, bj1+k1i1=bj1i1b^{i_1}_{j_1 + k_1} = b^{i_1}_{j_1}bj1​+k1​i1​​=bj1​i1​​ and all the terms in-between the two are unique, meaning that the cycle bi1b^{i_1}bi1​ is also a k1k_1k1​-cycle - in fact, by the above equalities, the cycle bi1b^{i_1}bi1​ is the exact same cycle as the cycle a1a^{1}a1. As disjoint cycles are commutative, the two cycles can be cancelled off from the equality; the same logic applied to all the above cycles yields the uniqueness of a single decomposition. □\square□

Lemma. If the permutation σ\sigmaσ has disjoint cycle decomposition (a11a21...ak11)...(a1ra2r...akrr)(a^1_1 a^1_2 ... a^1_{k_1})...(a^r_1 a^r_2 ... a^r_{k_r})(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)...(a1r​a2r​...akr​r​), then the order of σ\sigmaσ - i.e. the minimum value of kkk such that σk\sigma^kσk is the identity permutation - is the least common multiple of k1,...,krk_1, ..., k_rk1​,...,kr​.

Proof.

Let ord(σ)=k\text{ord}(\sigma) = kord(σ)=k; consider σk=(a11a21...ak11)k...(a1ra2r...akrr)k\sigma^k = (a^1_1 a^1_2 ... a^1_{k_1})^k...(a^r_1 a^r_2 ... a^r_{k_r})^kσk=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)k...(a1r​a2r​...akr​r​)k (as disjoint cycles are commutative). A kik_iki​-cycle has order kik_iki​, and as such, for σk\sigma^kσk to be the identity we must have

(a1ia2i...akii)k=identity(a^{i}_1 a^i_2 ... a^i_{k_i})^k = \text{identity}(a1i​a2i​...aki​i​)k=identity

for all iii, meaning that all of k1,...,krk_1, ..., k_rk1​,...,kr​ divide kkk.

(The above is true as if one of (a1ia2i...akii)k(a^{i}_1 a^i_2 ... a^i_{k_i})^k(a1i​a2i​...aki​i​)k is not the identity, σ\sigmaσ would necessarily modify the numbers a1i,a2i,...,akiia^i_1, a^i_2, ..., a^i_{k_i}a1i​,a2i​,...,aki​i​ to have different order, leaving σ\sigmaσ not equal to the identity.)

All that's left is to prove that kkk is the lowest such common multiple. Let l=lcm(k1,...,kr)l = \text{lcm}(k_1, ..., k_r)l=lcm(k1​,...,kr​); then we have

σl=(a11a21...ak11)l...(a1ra2r...akrr)l\sigma^l = (a^1_1 a^1_2 ... a^1_{k_1})^l...(a^r_1 a^r_2 ... a^r_{k_r})^lσl=(a11​a21​...ak1​1​)l...(a1r​a2r​...akr​r​)l

with

(a1ia2i...akii)l=((a1ia2i...akii)ki)a=identity(a^{i}_1 a^i_2 ... a^i_{k_i})^l = ((a^{i}_1 a^i_2 ... a^i_{k_i})^{k_i})^a = \text{identity}(a1i​a2i​...aki​i​)l=((a1i​a2i​...aki​i​)ki​)a=identity

for some integer aaa, by definition of the least common multiple. Thus lll satisfies σl=identity\sigma^l = \text{identity}σl=identity; as the order of σ\sigmaσ is defined as the minimum value of kkk such that σk\sigma^kσk is the identity, and any multiple of the LCM yields the identity, the lowest possible value of kkk is the LCM itself. □\square□
